outliers.description: Two significant outliers were identified in Campaign B using the IQR method: sales values of $650.30 and $580.70, which are more than 1.5 Ã— IQR above Q3. These extreme values skew the mean and increase the standard deviation for Campaign B.

data_exploration.visualization_insights: Campaign B shows a wider distribution with higher variability compared to Campaign A. While Campaign B has a higher mean and median, it also contains both lower minimums and higher maximums than Campaign A. The distribution of Campaign B appears right-skewed due to the outliers, while Campaign A shows a more symmetric distribution. Both campaigns show multimodal patterns corresponding to different income levels, with high-income customers generating consistently higher sales across both campaigns.

campaign_difference.interpretation: The t-test reveals a statistically significant difference between the mean sales of Campaign A and Campaign B (p < 0.05). Campaign B generated significantly higher sales on average, with approximately $41 more per customer. The confidence interval indicates we can be 95% confident that the true difference in means falls between $1.23 and $80.81.

regional_differences.interpretation: The two-way ANOVA indicates significant differences in campaign effectiveness across regions (p < 0.05). Campaign B outperformed Campaign A most dramatically in the South and West regions, while differences were smaller in the North and East regions. This suggests regional factors influence campaign effectiveness.

age_group.relationship_type: Inverted U-shaped relationship, with middle-aged groups (35-44, 45-54) showing the highest sales amounts, while youngest (18-24) and oldest (65+) groups show lower sales values.

income_level.relationship_type: Strong positive relationship, with high-income customers generating substantially higher sales than medium or low-income customers across both campaigns, but with a stronger effect in Campaign B.

satisfaction_correlation.interpretation: There is a strong positive correlation (r = 0.82) between customer satisfaction scores and sales amounts, which is statistically significant (p < 0.001). Higher satisfaction scores consistently correspond with higher sales values. This relationship holds across both campaigns, though Campaign B shows slightly higher satisfaction scores for comparable sales levels.

conclusions.most_effective_campaign: Campaign B was more effective overall, generating significantly higher average sales ($260.98 vs. $219.96). Despite greater variability and some very low values, Campaign B produced substantially higher maximum sales and better performance across most customer segments, particularly among high-income customers.
conclusions.regional_insights: Campaign effectiveness varied significantly by region. The South and West regions showed the largest differences between campaigns, with Campaign B substantially outperforming Campaign A. The North and East regions showed smaller differences. This suggests regional market factors or demographic compositions influence campaign effectiveness.
conclusions.demographic_insights: Income level was the strongest demographic predictor of sales performance, with high-income customers generating substantially higher sales in both campaigns. Campaign B was particularly effective with high-income customers. Middle-aged groups (35-54) responded better to both campaigns than younger or older customers.
recommendations: Prioritize Campaign B for future marketing efforts, especially targeting high-income customers
Focus Campaign B resources particularly in the South and West regions where it showed the strongest performance advantage
Target middle-aged demographic groups (35-54) for highest returns on marketing investment
Investigate factors contributing to higher customer satisfaction as it strongly correlates with increased sales
Consider a modified approach for low-income segments where Campaign B showed less advantage or even underperformed Campaign A
